												Does anyone remember the reputation this game got back in the days when it was released?! Well playing it now I think most reviews were....kinda harsh. Everyone was in teh DMC and God of War fan train back there and comparisons will not bring justince to X-Blades. So what is X-Blades?It`s a nice stylish spectacle fighter with a unique aesthetic back in those days, a great soundtrack and tight controls (the thing that most games like this lacked back then). Combos are the backbone of every spectacle fighter and here we have something...unique. Other than switching weapons here you can enchant your weapons with elemental damage so you can`t blame the game for not having 200 swords and another 100 firearms. Chaining attacks is fast and easy and the animations are superbe sincerely and the leves are also detailed and intriguing (even the arena style ones) giving the battles a nice atmosphere. I don`t know what to say about the game which was not said back in the original reviews but....it`s a great game actualy. Not as hard as most spectacle fighters but FUN. And that is the key word here: FUN! It`s fun to kill hundreds of demons with twin blades in over the top stylish combat sequnces.

												This game is better than it's reputation. Perhaps the fact that i have missed all those genre defining classics has made me look through the faults of this game because faults it does have: pacing, messy combat (at least in the beginning), Annoying main character with a fake 'i am the best' -attitude. Read that Bestiary when it updates. it really is worth your time as it directly tells what you are up against. Until then keep collecting those fragments and all the soulds you can find hidden in statues and clay pots. You will need them - literally millions of them. Luckily basic moves cost only some thousands that can be collected easily. Game is often offered in bundles very cheaply - i do recommend checking it out and giving it some time before deciding. It is quite satisfying to be able to easily trash a multitude of different types of enemies. Just be warned that the game really only shines once you start getting a good list of element powers and learn which move/element works on what.

content:
er 16, 2013
												I played the demo for Blades of Time, and I thought it was pretty good, so I bought it in a bundle and bought this with a 90% coupon I got for free.  To be honest, my expectations were low--X-Blades has a pretty poor reputation from what I've read, so it couldn't really go anywhere but up.  It took me nine hours to beat the game though I could've cut it down if I wasn't stuck in one portion.X-Blades is the story of a young woman in a skimpy outfit destroying statues and vases while slaughtering scores of monsters and critters.  I guess I'd classify it as a beat-em-up of sorts, the kind where the game will seal off an exit and you have to deplete a health bar on the bottom of the screen with enough monster death to continue.  Or maybe you have to find these monster generators and destroy all of them AND kill all of the monsters in the area to continue.  Combat is fairly simple, as you attack with your gunblades with slashes or shooting at distant enemies.  There's a Rage meter that rises with damage dealt and taken, which falls with time or when casting spells, as it's kinda like an MP bar in a way.  You gain Souls from enemies you butcher and the things you destroy, which you spend on learning new spells or getting in a quick anytime heal or Rage boost.  Battles are largely repetitive barring the boss battles.  You usually have enemies spawn in over a series of waves and you destroy them, or do the same with the monster generators, and then you get a Level Complete and you're free to explore the stages for artifact pieces to power up your attacks or other goodies.  All while staring at your character's ♥♥♥...I'm sorry, where was I?  There really aren't any puzzles to solve again barring some of the boss fights, and you typically get a bestiary update that tells you pretty much how to beat the foe.  This is the first game I've played where the bestiary updates BEFORE you kill something, but it's a handy hint system kinda thing.  For things the game did right...there's a pretty big variety of spells to spend your Souls on.  Granted there aren't many effects, but they are at least somewhat different.  Earthquake can't hit foes in the air, Ray of Light works best on darkness-aligned creatures, and Lightning Range is a kickass chain lightning spell.  There are only four quickslots for spells but you can call up the menu and cast a spell there if you have enough Rage, to make use of a few combos or to use something you don't have bound.  The music is a bit repetitive, being pretty heavy on the rock side during battles, but it kinda grew on me to be honest.  Even the title theme sounded bad...at first.  It's tolerable now, though I don't have to listen to it very much.  And the manual is written entirely in-character, which I realize is corny as hell but I kinda liked it.  There's also a results screen at the end of each stage so you can at least see if you missed any artifact pieces or are going for 100% completeness or something.  And you can go right back to the previous stage if you want, but no stage-select feature here, unfortunately.As for what I didn't like, some of the controls kinda bothered me.  There was a section I was stuck on that required crossing a chasm or fall to my death, and more than a few times did I accidentally dodge-roll right off a ledge when I meant to jump.  Dying in this game means you start the stage all over.  Did you get a Level Complete and die?  Too bad, start all over!  And this happened to me a few times.  Thankfully that section was optional and this game has no platforming sections like that anywhere else...and you get to keep all of the Souls you had already, so that's some consolation.  Another thing was that the battles were rarely fun and felt like grinding more than anything.  Even when you knew how to kill something, some things just took forever to die, and I hate attrition wars like that.  I did kinda like the game, but at no point did I really tell myself, "boy, this game is fun!" I honestly bought it just to see how bad it was, and it was cheap, so no major loss to me.  So I'm not recommending this.  I try to be patient with games, even ones that are said to be outright bad.  This one...it's okay, I guess, but I wouldn't recommend this to anybody, or really most people.  It's a rough game, it's trying quite a bit, and while I haven't played the games this gets compared to, it's largely mediocre and probably "a poor man's" version of those games at best.  The game likely will be remembered more for the outfit the protagonist wears than the content of the game, but all in all, it's not a bad game.  Just not one I'd see myself coming back to anytime soon.

												While not being a great game, it isn’t a complete waste, nor as bad as people make it out to be.The bad:-A completely boring, badly written story, that is completely throwaway, but thankfully doesn’t hinder you too often or too much.-Some enemies can be annoying beyond belief, mostly the flying ones and enemies you need to shoot with a special power.-A lot of throwaway attacks.-Repetitive. Slashing and shooting enemies from start to finish.-Below average boss fights that aren’t always explained well.The good:-Gameplay is decently fun, and it feels relatively good.-Graphics aren’t overly high-fidelity, but they still have a nice cartoonish look for them and are appealing to the eyes.-And yes, the main protagonist’s looks will probably carry this game for a lot of people.So taking everything in account, the game is nowhere as bad as people often make it out to be. Is it repetitive? Yes, very. Does it have huge mechanical faults? Yes, and you will notice them immediately if you have played any better games of this type. But if you just want a mediocre hack-and-slash with little variety and can ignore some faults and the absence of a proper story, the gameplay and its protagonist (as well as her behind) might be enough to keep you invested and entertained. If you can’t overlook some of those bigger faults, and solid gameplay and aesthetics aren’t enough to convince you to spend money on it, you might want to give it a pass. Otherwise, this is a solid little time-sinker for fans of the genre which I recommend buying at any sale.

												X-Blades greatest flaw is its redundancy. Enemies, environments and actions will all be extremely familiar territory by the end of the adventure. This isn't helped by the fact that the first portion of X-Blades is spent working your way through arenas in the light of day, then turning around working your way back through those arenas in the evening. It's a serious copout on the part of the developers to not create new architecture and instead relight the same areas. A copout that should not go unnoticed. What's Good:- The game offers a nice challenge- Does a great job at encourging a variety of approaches in battle- Plenty of upgrades to purchase- Rewarding collectibles- Good variety gunplay- The heavy role magic plays in combatWhat's Not-So-Good:- Battles can be repetitive- Lack of variety in music- Uneven difficulty in boss battles (ridiculously easy final boss)- A few visual errorsWhat's Bad:- Overly sensitive movement controls - ^ Unresponsive aerial movements- Very poor storytelling- ZERO character development- Pointless levels- Penatlizing players for buying life refills with very little alternatives- Lack of variety in sword comboIn all, there are certain aspects of X-blades that are well developed while there are many others that are not. Depending on your level of tolerance, it can be a decent experience.

												If I had to describe the game in one word, it would be an unflattering "Competent". The game brings nothing new to the table, nothing innovative, nothing exciting and different. It's formulaic and is merely competent at the formula. The main attraction seems to be the near nudity of the main character, the clothes go to a level of lunacy most games of this visual style don't, and the weapons are simplistic and uninspired. You get a pair of gunblades and you either slash your way through wave after wave of enemies, or shoot them, or mix it up and do both. You will learn some new abilities by finding artifact pieces which add new skills for shooting things and hitting them with swords. The artifacts are arguably essential, as they unlock combos and more combos are useful, so you'll have to hunt these things down to have an alternative to clicking one of the two mouse buttons repeatedly. As long as you can crank the resolution up on your display, the controls are fine, if amazingly uninspired. If you have to use a lower resolution for performance the mouse becomes unplayably twitchy and fast. My one complaint would be that the entire game is one formula. You enter an area and fight off some sort of boss monster. You fight either a boss, waves of smaller enemies, atatck stationary things until the bar is depleted and things stop spawning; then you kill the remaining ones and get to move onto the next area where you repeat the process. Sometimes you'll have it easier and have to run through an area avoiding arguably simple obstacles with dodge, or running through a puzzle of blades. Those would be a lot easier if the game explained the controls well, but following the game exactly results in dodge and other moves being wildly inconsistent to do. There is nothing inspired or amazing about this game, but it's a hack and slash. If you like just hitting things with swords, it does it just well enough that i can't say I recommend avoiding the game. It's not terribly good, but it can be enjoyable enough if very repetitive. I would not play the game again after completion unless achievements were added or some other incentive, as it is the game is acceptable enough to get a playthrough and then be left alone.

												Sometimes I wish I didn't get crap like this in bundles so I wouldn't be tempted to play it. Then I play it anyway and wonder why I didn't listen to myself.If you're really into button mashing, have I got the game for you. This game is all about slamming on the attack button against fodder enemies (combos are for wimps) until your rage (read: mana) meter is filled up enough to use the earthquake ability you unlock during the tutorial to kill them all and then use whatever rage you have left after that to spam whatever other ability the boss you're fighting is weak to. Of course, they have so much health that it'll still take several minutes, but you also have just as much, and they telegraph their attacks so much that it's impossible to die unless you walk away from the computer. The only time that pattern was not repeated before I stopped playing was in an area without a boss, and then it was just button mash to kill lots of enemies without a boss instead.It's like they realized they'd made a game that was only 90 minutes long and kind of sucked (yes, other stuff sucks, like the lockon picking the wrong thing most of the time, the camera being a little flaky, every single animation in the air being totally wonky and waaaaaay too slow/floaty, including jumping and the earthquake attack you'll be constantly using, frightening amounts of lens flare/bloom...), so they added an extra zero to the end of the health of everything. There are absolutely much worse games out there, but there aren't a lot of games that feel more tedious.If you really want to run around with no pants on, take your pants off right now. You have my permission. No matter where you are and no matter what happens, it'll be more fun than the game.

ry 24, 2015
												Alright. When I started writing more reviews, I told myself that I should do so after finishing the game. But this here. This game. I... can't wait until I've finished this mess before I write down what exactly I think of X-Blades.You see, the game suffers from three big R's. Repetition, Recycling, and Redundancy. How so?RedundancyFor a start, you'll be spammed - SPAMMED, I tell you - with the same enemy type in one of the mind-numbingly short levels for minutes. You better have a durable thumb (or forefinger, depending on wether you play this with a controller or keyboard and mouse), because you'll have to spam back attacks to control those monster hordes. And it's not really entertaining at all. This will go on for every single level. Even the boss battles. You'll be swarmed by mobs.RepetitionIt's not bad enough that the level design is already redundant with the endless monster hordes. Oh no, it gets worse. Because every single level will be the same. Bit of running around, bit of smashing things, button mashing, next level. Rinse and repeat. Rinse and repeat. I last for about 2 or so levels per sitting. I just can't do much more because it's so incredibly badly made.RecyclingOh dear. They did not. - Hell yes, they did.See, it's not bad to use a level again at a later point in time, in maybe slightly altered form, to give the game a nice little looping back. But X-Blades takes it to a sadly very, very lazy extreme. See... you go through the whole dungeon twice. At day and at night. The exact. Same. Rooms. And you do the exact. Same. Thing. Again.For a game which claims to be of the Hack and Slash genre, X-Blades does a terrible job at introducing something which makes it stand out in the genre. The claims of the reviews that X-Blades is anywhere near as good as DMC is preposterous, even ridiculous. You better check out Metacritic first, and maybe a gameplay video on Youtube. Also, you should probably search for something superior to this.Even if the game is a bit over 5 years old, this is no excuse at being so utterly terrible. 2009 brought us Overlord II, Dragon Age Origins, and Batman Arkham Asylum.Think about this.THINK ABOUT IT.And keep your hands away from X-Blades.Oh, in a slightly belated addition: I didn't talk about the gameplay, story, and any of that, did I now? Well. If any of it had been good, I miiiight have forgiven the triple-R offense of the game. But sadly, nothing noteworthy of a story to be found here.The gameplay and controls feel stiff and rather ininspired. I played with an X-Box 360 Controller for Windows, and, bad as that is, I sometimes didn't notice the controller had lost power and disconnected from the receiver. It took me several seconds to even bother to check the controller at times, since X-Blades's controls have the tendency to feel a little sticky, at least to me.Next, I'd like to talk about the music briefly. Sadly, the tracks are repetitive, and the in-game music was much too loud for my taste. I had to reduce it to near silence to be able to enjoy the music even remotely. That being said, it was most of the times highly unfitting for the current mood of the game, or at least what I perceived to actually be the intended mood. A tense moment was completely shot to pieces by much too heavy and fast-paced rock music (double offense for the track being the bad, generic kind), and the rest of the time, the music wasn't really adding anything for me. In fact, it felt more like background noise of the obnoxious kind.Tiny little excourse to the voice-acting - there actually is some in the game! For some reason, even though I selected English as language, the voice-acting was in German... and... meh. MEH. Sorry, but it really, really destroyed the game even more. The voices didn't fit, they sounded uninspired, and the bickering back and forth between Ayumi and the dark wolf boss thingy was painfully childish and immature. Unnecessary, in other words.Oh, right, the story. To be honest, since I don't plan on finishing the game (yeah... there's only so much mind-numbing stupidity I can deal with), I have nooo idea what the story is about. And even as I read up on it, it seems like it is all over the place. Something of an artifact, someone being possessed, getting repossessed, un-possessed... whatever. I have no idea. I really don't.Maybe I should also add something about the character design. Good? Good. Or rather, bad. See, there are sexy heroines in tight, short outfits, and then there's Ayumi. I actually felt horribly uncomfortable with her. She looks much too young to wear little more than straps passing as an excuse for clothes. I don't view her as sexy. She has some adorable about her, and that makes things really awkward really fast. Add to that the uninspired childish bickering mentioned in the voice-acting paragraph of the review, and it gets really, really, REALLY awkward and weird.So, with that added to the already terribly done R's... nope. Not looking any good here, X-Blades. I'm going to play Alice: Madness Returns next, to have some really good Hack and Slash.

content:
er 27, 2016
												X-blades tells a tale of a brash treasure hunter, Ayumi, whose lack of caution brings her trouble when she steals an artifact from a temple. After experiencing the effects of the artifact's curse, the protagonist is somehow transported onto the beach of some ruins and from there she makes her way through the ruins. After three to four hours of playing, I have dropped the game as I haven't seen much good in what I have experienced.First, the voice of the protagonist is kind of grating in a bratty way. I think the intent for the character was for her to be absolutely sure of her abilities, as in "I'm the greatest treasure hunter in the world," but the voice doesn't pair well with Ayumi who shows disregard for caution. Instead of exuding confidence, when she publically makes this claim, it makes her come off as an immature kid which makes it hard to take her seriously. Maybe she gets better later in the story, but the rest of the game isn't good enough to compel me to continue.Second, the basic aerial sword combat is unsatisfying. While on the ground, her swinging of her sword and contacting enemies feels alright. Her jumping, however, is very floaty which makes air combat strange to execute against aerial monsters. It is difficult to quickly determine how many hits that are launched are actually damaging the enemies or whether she's just floating and waving her swords around, especially when the camera angle is not facing the enemies. Considering that swordplay against enemies is the main way of building up a rage meter that is used for launching spells, improvement in this would have made a major contribution in making the game better.This lackluster air sword combat then ties into her heavy dependence on long-ranged skills and guns to attack aerial monsters. The problem is that the pistols take at least a few shots to bring down one enemy, assuming that the enemy isn't an elemental type that's immune to physical damage, and spells require rage to use, which builds up very slowly when using her guns. Ayumi can technically charge up rage while standing still and pressing the appropriate button but then she becomes an easier target for enemies. Not only that, but rage depletes over time, so she can build up rage for a short moment and then have to flee, whereupon she starts to lose rage. The alternative way is to get hit by enemies which allows her to quickly build range and launch spells but then she can only take so much damage before she dies. I think the frustration with this is a bit evident based on how having an unsatisfying air sword combat results in having to rely on long-range attacks that most of the time can be equally disappointing. Now having a poor air sword combat and long-range attacks would not be as big of a deal if there were few aerial monsters. Unfortunately, these type of enemies occur quite frequently and very commonly in groups which makes them the most annoying enemies to deal with. Elemental aerial types are even worse if there are more than a few of them, especially if the player didn't purchase the correct spells to deal with their elemental weakness.Another part that bothered me is the pricing of the spells and its related issues. To purchase spells, Ayumi has to collect souls, either by defeating enemies or destroying destructible objects such as statues, and she can earn spells at a faster rate by continuously hitting enemies with her swords without taking damage whereupon a multiplier with its value dependent on the number of attacks successfully executed. The beginning spells seem to be priced reasonably, but after the first few purchases, the pricing seem to sky rocket all over the place and with each spell purchase the subsequent spell can cost on the scale of ten times more. So how does this become a problem?  If a player commits to buying some pricy spells, it can bite them back when facing off against a mini-boss or boss who can be defeated much easier with spells that weren't purchased.  The player might not even be good enough and will die repeatedly, and if the person is only relying on auto-save for his game, he's going to be respawning and repeatedly fighting the same boss because the game loads from the beginning of the level. And the soul multiplier? That is actually useful against enemies on the ground but pretty much useless against aerial enemies who are more likely to get a hit onto a Ayumi every time she attempts air combat.Lastly, the plot is too haphazard.  The plot starts off relatively well with background on the main character and the disaster she gets herself into for taking the artifact, but after entering the ruins on the beach, it feels like it falls on the wayside as the game transitions into a repetition of entering a level, wiping the enemies, and going onto the next level. Cutscenes occasionally occur but the transitions into them are abrupt. There is a lack of continuity which makes if feel like plot points are suddenly tacked on to give a semblance of a story and that is disappointing given the start of the game.Having said all of the negatives, there are a few positives that can be said about this game. The environments are interesting and well-varied. They're not particularly sophisticated in level design but are nice to look at and show the ambition of the developer in terms of environmental design. Although stylistically different, the cutscenes are great and fluid, showing off the anime style very well. The game looks great, but I wish the rest of the game matched the style of the cutscenes although I imagine that would be hard to pull off.  Ayumi's AOE spells are satisfying to use as they give a distinct visual impact when execute, in contrast to the lackluster basic combat.Overall, I can't really recommend the game unless you're a huge fan of the hack-and-slash genre and are scraping the bottom of the barrel. You're much better off playing the spiritual successor, Blades of Time, which improves on all aspects of the game.

												X-Blades is a very hard game to review. It's a mixed bag of great ideas with somewhat poor execution. Visually environments look stunning but there is no cohesive artstyle. Menus and graphical effects really cheapen the games look. Animations are far too simple, bland and don't feel rewarding when you land a combo or hit. The gameplay itself is standard. It's a level based hack and slash game with slight free-roaming elements as you swap between areas. Most levels involve hoardes of enemies rushing at you, but unlike in other games such as dynasty warriors, the lack of feedback or spectacle make things teadious quickly. Some bosses and enemies require special strategies but have no visual way of iterating that to the player. This forces you to read the in game hints on the pause menu.X-Blades has a lot of small gameplay issues, but the problems above are the big dissapointments. It could have been a good game with annoying faults but is left utterly medicore with so much wasted potential.

content:
r 13, 2016
												X-Blades is a mediocre hack and slash title which suffers from repetitive gameplay.You play as Ayumi, a confident treasure hunter who would rather fly solo than share the loot with her teammates. She finds a map leading her to ancient ruins in the hope of finding an artifact of incredible power. The story is very brief is mostly just there to glue the levels together. Immediately apparent is Ayumi's eye-catching appearance (with jiggle physics) in an attempt to sell through sex-appeal and honestly, it's why I played the game in the first place. Just know that it's a budget title beforehand and don't set your expectations too high.One of the main criticisms I have is with the game's structure over the course of its 40 levels. It can be broken up into 2 parts: the first 20 levels taking place in the daytime and latter 20 being the same levels but only in the evening. The second-half isn't an exact copy of the first but you'll definitely get a sense of déjà-vu as you backtrack through most of the same rooms again only with a darker color change and different monsters to kill.Using your twin gunswords, Ayumi can slash, shoot and use magic to vanquish foes. This rewards you with 'souls' which is used as currency to purchase new attacks, abilities, spells, damage upgrades etc. You can only have 4 magic abilities active at any one time but they can be swapped around during gameplay. Magic usage is dependent on your rage bar which is filled either by hitting enemies or getting hit yourself.  Strategy is involved as certain enemies can only be defeated by using certain attacks e.g. fire magic against ice enemies or a monster is only weak against guns. You'll know which attacks are effective because the game has a bestiary which sometimes updates before fighting a monster. Sadly the occasions which you have to use specific tactics to kill enemies are quite rare that most of the time the basic attack and starter magic skill 'earthquake' sufficiently clears the level. Large magic skills also plays a short animation before every use, which can get old quickly. Where the combat does shine though is in its boss battles as they require slightly different tactics than the usual normal mobs.How standard gameplay works is like this: you'll enter a level and a red bar will appear at the bottom right of your screen. You will be locked into that level while waves of enemies spawn around you. Defeating them will reduce the bar and once it's empty, the level is cleared and you're free to explore or progress to the next stage. Rinse and repeat. There are a couple of platforming rooms without combat but these are few and far between. The game will throw hordes of enemies at you and a few stages towards the end were very frantic with seemingly endless amount of enemies. Couple this with the button-mashing gameplay and it can get monotonous.There are collectables in the game as the end of each level shows a stats screen which details valuables/artifacts and objects destroyed. Often times I found myself clearing a level of monsters and then proceeding to slash and shoot every statue and pot in sight to get 100% level completion. They award souls and rare price discounts on skill upgrades while artifacts power up your attacks. Also there was strange hit detection when hunting for breakable items, on many occasions my sword attacks did nothing at point blank range until I moved around to find the sweet spot. Hit feedback is another issue as swinging your swords through enemies feels like you're just sliding through them and while being surrounded all the time, it can be difficult to notice you're even getting hit unless you break away from the hypnotizing button-mashing to look at your health bar. The double-jump button timing can be very short and you end up unintentionally performing a single jump, falling short of your goal and sometimes leading to death. It too relies on spamming the button to execute consistently.The game is very short lasting around 4-5 hours. After completion, there are incentives to start a 2nd playthrough with an unlockable 'Pro' difficulty and bonus costumes which provide additional abilities. There are also multiple endings which are triggered by what skills you've learned by the end of the game.Graphics-wise, the game exceeded my expectation for a budget title with decent textures and a beautiful, vivid color palette considering the time of original release (Oniblade in 2007). The game looked good in motion with all the combat spell effects and godrays in 60fps. Despite this, the game isn't demanding and runs well on low-end hardware, Windows 10 and is fully compatible with an Xbox 360 controller. No crashes throughout my experience either.While fighting, an instrumental soundtrack of rocking guitars will play which helps you feel like a badass as you slaughter hundreds of monsters. During some moments, the game will switch to an orchestral score to give that epic battle feeling. Music and sound effects were generally good except that the guns lacked a sense of lethality to them.Overall, the game has the essence of Devil May Cry but the level design and core gameplay do little to provide a satisfying experience among the monotony of killing rooms of enemies over and over again. The combat is fast and responsive however it devolves into spamming X and the same magic skills.Usually a cute girl is enough to carry me through a game but unfortunately this wasn't the case in X-Blades. Dat ♥♥♥ though...Mmm...

Except the fact is that I didn't have any fire moves like they wanted me to have and I didn't have enough souls to buy the fire move. Now WTF is that? 10 mins in and you couldn't program for a lack of souls? There was actually no possible way for me to move on other than reloading the game completely. Aside from that, the movement blur was really distracting and it was way excessive compared to Blades of Time.If the gameplay and bugs weren't so bad, I probably would have liked this game because I actually liked the environment crafting and design for the most part. The graphics weren't that bad for its style of game and the music was pretty good for the game.This game is basically a buggy and worse version of Blades of Time, which is actually really fun and good. I cannot recommend this game, but I do recommend that everyone play Blades of Time instead.Rating: 6.8/10Recommend Price: Under $1

												I don't play much hack and slash games, so playing this title has earnt its originality in my eyes.   I myself am acquainted with old visuals and have grown very fond of this particularly because of its rigid graphics and textures. By playing this game, it gives my brain a break from the freakishly new realistic AAA games out there. The gaming world is evolving so fast that I cannot keep up with the advancements; hence I linger behind and give this dead game my time worth playing. Many people complain that this game is too repetitive. I am a human with daily routines that are in fact, highly repetitive. It’s a fact that we humans are repetitive. So I am used to the repetition. It’s not painfully repetitive, the game does throw you something new to fight, new items to obtain and with the new items you can fight new bosses, with different environments. Granted it’s a low budget game so they recycled most of gameplay from time to time, but this just helps you grind your way to get those new items you’ve been saving up for. The soundtrack is amazing, no other words for that. I did not care about the storyline so much because this game is just pure stress relief. The story is average, simply when I play this game; you got to be in the mood for killing. I’m sorry; you just can’t expect to play this game for just the story.    Many people prefer devil may cry over this game. This is because DmC is way polished, but I couldn’t be bothered to play DmC, so playing blades of time has been such a cheap experience you got to play for yourself. My rating:  7.98/10 so that’s 79.8% as a personal metacritic score.   It is an underrated gem in my opinion, which will soon grow to become a cult classic in years to come.

												Whilst I got this game through a contest on /v/, it's surprisingly entertaining. That is, once you get past the slippery controls, mentally handicapped AI, shotty animations, shotty hit detections, broken map system, incredibly bland as well as douchey characters, and 'Pleb' tier story telling. To start off, the tutorials in the beginning of the game are very vague, which left me trying to figure out just wth I was doing. For the controls, it is tight for the most part, but half of the time when you try to perform a double jump, Ayumi will fail to do so despite pressing the right buttons. As for the goal? Find it and get to it, once you've defeated all the enemies. Half way through the game, it gives you no indication as where to go and the broken map didn't help either. The music on the other hand was fairly decent, reminding me of "Sonic Adventure's" soundtrack. While some tracks where bland, the fighting music is where the soundtrack really shines. Upbeat and hard driven, the fighting music really gets you in the mood to slash some baddies, although I'm fairly certain they stole some of the riffs from various artists.Anyways, if you enjoy animu babes and gunblades, then this game is for you.

												This feels like it was an okay premise for a game that was never finished.  The combat has no weight to it, the story is perfunctory at best, and you will essentially be locked in an arena fighting the same monsters over and over with your poor combat mechanics until you're able to move on to the next round.  The visuals are flashy on your character and combat moves, but you're going to see the same enemy models over and over, and little to no details were put into the environments.  I think the studio shows promise, but their next title will need a lot more work if they want a product to catch on.

												I absolutely loved Blades of Time so I bought this, its predecessor, but this really doesn't measure up. What I loved so much in Blades of time was the gloriously fun and intuitive combat but this game has rubbish, awkward combat with clunky fighting animations and difficult button sequences for special moves. The level design is disappointing, in each area then have to kill waves of enemies till it unlocks the door to the next area. To make some boss fights more difficult they are invulnerable to all but one arbitrary colour of magic. Of the reviews I have seen this game is heavily slated but it is not that bad. Don't get me wrong this is not a good game but it isn't as terrible as most of the reviews suggest, there is still some fun to be had here. If you are contemplating this game I'd get advocate getting Blades of Time instead it is massively better than this. I wouldn't really recommend getting this but I also wouldn't tell you to run for the hills if you are considering it.

I'm usually an atheist, but, Jesus Christ.If you like this game, I won't judge you, but I'm removing this from my account and I'm never touching it again, If I can avoid it. 												Okay, let me start with saying this game is alright. The graphics are good (But really, who's looking at the graphics when your camera is always behind the heroine? Hint, hint.), the controls are alright but are better when using an controller, and the soundtrack is amazing. Now on to the bad things. The backstory really isn't explored much, pretty much being told through a timeline feature, and the game doesn't really give you hints on how to beat some enemies. I spent five minutes trying to kill one enemy, only to find out I had to look in the bestiary section to find out it was weak to fire. Really? Couldn't have had it come up before the fight or even during it after two minutes passed? But, I digress. Overall, not a bad game. Would I go out of my way to buy this? Maybe. 												Okay, you are looking at the game on steam, see it's a beat 'em up, it looks kinda interesting (You know you want that half naked chick with swords), and you are thinking "should I try it?"Here's a simple answer: No.Seriously, unless it's -80% you shouldn't even consider.The game is extremely repetive, and dull. The game pretty much rides on the whole "here's a girl (with the classic idiot blonde feel) in skimpy clothes, please buy." The combat is very simple, you just smash that attack button, and things die. And just because it wouldn't be fun to just slash everything down, the game throws literally a hundred flying creatures at you, that you simply have to "shoot" with your miserable guns, while strafing and browsing reddit on your second monitor or something. Oh and each time you use a proper spell, everything stops and you get to watch the same freaking cutscene, boss fights at best are 50% of watching the same spell cutscene, 40% hacking stuff up for rage to use it, 10% getting hit by something and waiting for your great agile heroine to recover from the nudge.The combat is so bad that it makes me want to cry, there's no story to speak of, the voice acting is horrible imo, and plaftorming/puzzles = jumping over spikes in a small room that just go around in the same pattern for 5 minutes. Not worth your time. The only thing I could give any credit for, is the soundtrack, which too gets old when the same song plays for the 5th time.

content:
12, 2014
												Pretty bad through and through.X-Blades starts looking bad right from the cover art - a near naked girl with what looks like a metal thong resting in an incredibly peculiar way on her buns. But hey, Blades of Time (the sequel which I played before this) had the same problem, yet surprised me with some really good ideas, so I gave X-Blades the benefit of the doubt and played all the way through. Spoiler: there's _nothing_ redeeming about this game.I've never heard more laughable voice acting, but chances are you won't have to hear it because voices generally couldn't be heard over the game's other sounds. Complete subtitle de-synchronization is the cherry on top. It's for the best really because the "banter" is cringe-worthy and you'd probably rather just have it on mute. Luckily, they don't repeat lines very often.-Story-The story... watch the second opening cut-scene and just listen to Ayumi's monolog. Now imagine 9 hours more of that intensity of bad. It never gets as high as mediocre- it stays firmly at that concentration of terrible. They try to give Ayumi a character arc- she's a no nonsense self reliant gal and she don't need no ones help! Oh no, she fell into a basic trap! Luckily there's a man nearby to save her. Then.... I just finished the game and I don't remember exactly how the plot unfolds- it's really a mess. He runs off after saving her, they both meet up two other times by coincidence to fight another guy. Worth noting that no one has any given motivation whatsoever. Ayumi wants some treasure but that didn't work out by the third cut-scene, so what follows is Ayumi wandering around aimlessly until the three characters meet up and fight, apparently for lack of anything better to do. Blah blah blah the guy who saved Ayumi from the trap (with whom she has spent a total of 5 minutes with) is possessed by evil powers and she is forced to fight him. You'd think he was her long lost lover by the way she acts when confronting him. The whole plot is really disjointed and Ayumi's character arc advances abruptly and with apparent reason, creating a really confusing and inconsistent personality.-Game play-For the first few hours of the game you basically have only three powers, and they're "dark". Dark is bad and Ayumi trades them for light powers at some point in an incredibly confusing cutscene. There are two endings in the game, and you get the "evil" end if you've upgraded any of the dark powers. So... if you ever used the upgrade system at any point 4 hours into the game, you'll be getting the evil end. And there was no indication of this. OK, I'm not actually opposed to the idea of this mechanic, but I'm not replaying the 9 hours it took me to finish this game just for an equally terrible "good" ending (which I looked up on YouTube). Spoiler alert- in the evil end you're unable to kill the guy without killing him for real and Ayumi is very very sad about this as evidenced by a cut-scene showing her being very sad. Yay character development. It's a fitting end for her character arc.So you don't care about story and just want to watch the boob jiggle physics while killing things? This game almost delivers on that. Almost. I'm of the opinion that the fact it is a crappy console port kicks it out of "meh time-killer" to "don't waste your time".Brief overview; initially the combat is repetitive, but you gain powers and abilities as the game goes on. I played the hardest difficulty, which required a modest amount of grinding, nothing to complain about. I actually wanted to grind to unlock more powers, because they were somewhat interesting and alleviated the repetitiveness and could be chained together in ways indicative of some intelligent game design. Occasionally you could not proceed without a particular power, so you'll have to run to previous rooms, fighting re-spawned enemies to collect enough souls to purchase a power. You'll never know which power you'll need though as winning these rooms is part puzzle, part trial and error, so if you don't like grinding, guess correctly when purchasing. There was also a system by which you get a multiplier for long combos, which provided some artificial difficulty and much needed mental stimulation for me.Sounds decent so far, right? A large set of powers, incentive to buy and use them, some puzzles that require stringing a few of these powers together, and a multiplier system for self imposed challenges when the game gets a bit too easy. However, it just isn't fun for one reason: crappy console port. There are something like 25 unlock-able powers, and you can only use 4 at a time. Picture this: clicking through mouse driven menus three levels deep in order to shuffle 25 powers around the 4 slots. Any flow this game might have had is just -lost-. You map powers to what would be the d-pad. If they had just let PC users map each power to say, any given key on the keyboard, or had some sort of quick switch menu, this game could have been decent on game play alone. I suspect the people who are giving this game mildly good reviews also enjoy using some ancient version of MS excel- these menus are mouse driven only, no keyboard shortcuts. I considered automating the switching of powers with macros (program a key to automatically click around the menu as fast as they appear), but I never got around to it before reaching the end of the game.-tl;dr-There's nothing worth experiencing here- but the sequel, Blades of Time (for which I have also written a review) , is vastly improved by comparison. It's just a better version of this game. If you're at all interested in X-Blades for some reason, know that there's nothing to see here- Blades of Time is mechanically similar and isn't a complete waste of time.Update: The above said, I have the strangest desire to go back to this game. The experience was sub par at the time, but it certainly leaves a good memory.Edit- I forgot to mention that the combat upgrades are odd. There's a combination of poor instructions, awkward controls / weird timing, and poor visual feedback so that you couldn't tell if you were doing the new unlocked combo at all. In the beginning I would frequently stop and examine Ayumi's attack animations: "Is that different than normal? I think maybe she did something different here..." ... I eventually stopped trying to figure it out. When I could actually, without a doubt, see a move distinctly different from the usual flailing swords, it was always clunky and something you'd never actually want to use in the heat of the moment. Pity too- the dodge/jump thing could have been good. Speaking of that, an example of the how poor the instructions are: I had to minimize the game and look on gamefaqs to learn how to do it, as the game wouldn't let me continue without it. The game literally forced me to jump under falling blades- if I tried using my teleporting power I would appear on the other side of the blade dead. And IIRC dodge/jump never comes up again, so at the end of the day we have a hard to trigger, improperly explained move that is brought up exactly once but you can't continue playing until you've proved you can do it.

												I haven't finished the game yet, but from what I've played so far... It just lacks polish...The main character is an idiot. The storyline so far is literally (and this is in the first few minutes, so it's no a spoiler, per se):She's a treasure hunter. She wants a special treasure.She finds it, and is told by the guardian of the treasure... Do NOT touch it, it's deadly and dangerous.She tells him that she can handle herself and grabs it anyway, causing whatever type of mayhem that I haven't really seen yet.The levels are fairly large and have hidden items to find in them... after you defeat your enemies, because during the fight you really have to focus.Unfortunately, the levels are poorly designed and the only benefit of a large level is that they can hide items. The battles usually take place in a very small space where button mashing is your best bet.The fighting system itself has nice controls (using an Xbox controller) but the fights themselves are spamming attack until you can use a skill or if you're in one of the bullcrap fights. Shooting your guns (which offers no "Rage" [used for skills]) which means you have to take damage in order to use your skills. The alternative is to use the very underpowered guns and try to kill everything.The boss battles aren't challenging and just drag on. Luckily, when I saw the giant crab-like boss, I was curious. So, I opened my bestiary.It gives details about his weaknesses and strengths. But no where does the game tell you to look at it, or offer a tip stating that the bestiary can help. Even with knowing his weaknesses, the battle still dragged on to become tedious instead of fun.----So, overall... tedious battles with poorly designed levels and a main character that I want to punch in the face.idk if the story is good yet... being that the rest of the design is poor, I doubt the story gets any better.

												My first negative review. I really wanted to like this game. An action adventure/hack-n-slash game, with some Metroidvania style level design, highscores, and an attractive (if a bit sexualized) heroine? Sign me up. Unfortunately, the formula definitely is a lot better in theory rather than practice. The PC controls are clunky to say the least (I don't have game pad, maybe this improves things), and unresponsive. For a game that is combat focused and combo heavy, this is most certainly a black mark. The layout of the levels is dull (every area is basically another large arena), and enemies respawn everytime you pass through an area. This is particularly annoying if you have to get through an area which has some annoying gimic to it (destroying enemy spawners, for instance). The aesthetic of the levels were neat though. The story was also especially lack luster, and with lacking exposition I couldn't tell you why things where happening, even if I wanted to. Also, that attractive heroine? Easily the most grating part of the game. I wish she'd kindly shut up everytime a cut-scene came up. The kinda girl that's definitely ONS status, if she were real. Anyway, unless you're willing to wade through all that, I would most certainly NOT recommend this. Double A, for Absolutely Abysmal.

er 15, 2014
												X-blades is a straight up hack and slash game, an "okay" one at that. but there are a few things that need pointing outgameplay: early gameplay is honestly very, very lacking. its a classic hack and slash, so you pretty much just mash buttons, there are no combos to do whatsoever or anything of the sort, so you will only see and use the same moves for the whole game. the game might give combos later in the game (doubt that), but in the few early levels, no combos means boring as sh!t gameplay which is going to turn off a lot of people to continue. theres the "rage" meter which powers up your skills, it increases when you are hitting, getting hit or charging up your skills to fill your rage. the rage will go down after a few seconds if its not being used so it will indirectly encourage skill spamming and thats not exactly fun to spam the same skills. which brings it to my next point, the early boss has quite a health. not challenging but its a brick, it doesnt do much to you but takes a billion hits to die, not to mention the game mechanic wants you to only be able to kill certain enemies with certain skills, further encouraging skill spam. the first few bosses have me just run around, kill minions to get rage, and shoot the boss. keep doing that until it dies.thats not very fun , especially in a boss fight, which should be exciting and makes your adrenaline run.graphics: for the time it was released, i guess it counts as pretty good even though it kinda looks like a ps2 game, which isnt very eye candy. the world design, is not exactly compelling either, but it works. the character model looks like the type that will start an internet flame as she is only wearing something that resembles a thong of some sort.not much to say here.story: story is definitely not this game's strong point because its just not that interesting, pretty cliche and predictable.you probably wont remember the story after beating this game.music: so far ive been hearing the same soundtrack getting played a couple of times, but its not earbleeding or anything. its okay.overall not a fun game, but this is the first few levels, which usually the point where it either hooks players or make them turn away. i heard people say the end game is more fun, but with this kind of mechanic im not sure how much more fun there is waiting for me later on. i wouldnt recommend this, and definitely not at full price. got this game on sale at 1$ so i guess i cant complain that much. perhaps if you are really bored or just in case the internet is down you might want this game, but theres a lot of games that are free and waaay better than this one.

y 9, 2015
												Even at the low low price of 99 cents it is impossible to recommend this game. With graphics befitting a 2008 Unity game that even thongs and jiggle physics can't save, and controls worse than a fever dream, X-blades is an entirely unrewarding experience. Your adversaries are either ripped apart like the tissue paper in a sports bar urinal or take an unneccesary number of swings to kill. Jumping is clunky and aerial combat is near impossible. When faced with numerous mobs, they suffer little to no knockback, meaning that if in your bored tyrade of 'click repeatedly to use sword on mans' you start to take damage, you stagger and your health can be depleted fairly rapidly. There is an illusion of variety in combat, but it ultimately boils down to clicking on everything repeatedly until it stops moving,  and if your blades don't kill it, shoot it or throw fireballs at it until it dies.X-Blades also opens with cinematics - albeit in an entirely different art style - but then ends abruptly when you are transitioned from stage to stage with no advancing in the "storyline" or any idea what your purpose is for being there. Although not as polished as similar titles like God of War or Devil May Cry, this games spiritual successor "Blades of Time" is all around a better experience. Save your dollar and buy a Snickers or something.

The Targeting system works, but sometimes it doesn't, so it can be hard to hit that enemy. As the character has a wide range of attack, it almost serves the purpose of making for the flaws of the target, but it doesn't.Also, the magic may take a while to charge, which is not really fun, even though you don't use mana.Well, you can buy this game, it has some good elements of fun and you can appreciate the game. content:
5, 2015
												I look at the reviews for X-Blades on the page and I honestly find myself baffled. Review after review recommending this game that I honestly wish I had never bought. In the interest of honesty, I will disclose that I only bought X-Blades at the request of a friend, with the promise of lunch at a hibachi steakhouse if I got the good ending. And as good as the steak and shrimp was, I'm not completely sure if it was worth it. I'll start with the story. What little story there is is so incredibly generic one could get the main gist with a few key words. Blah blah blah treasure. Blah blah blah Darkness. Blah blah blah ancient power. blah blah blah. This doesn't stop the main characters, though. I suppose just having a story is a major accomplishment for an entity as relatable as the half-eaten bag of crackers in my trash can. This is only half due to the inherent flatness of the characters though. The other half is because of the incompetence of the voice actors. Each and every line is delivered like the person standing behind the microphone has a gun to their head. The incredibly threatening recording sessions obviously having taken place weeks apart and in different locations. Then they just stitched the recordings together like someone trying to make a car by sewing construction paper together with string. The visual design is actually alright, feels like it's a bit behind the times. It would look fantastic on a PS2, but it falls short on modern consoles. The sound design is back and forth, as the music is good, but each individual sound effect feels like a tiny murder every time it plays. And finally, we come to gameplay, arguably the make-or-break point of game design. It's repetitive. It's incredibly repetitive. I honestly can't imagine why anybody outside of an insane asylum would play this game the entire way through without the promise of chicken and shrimp. If you aren't using the weightless melee attack, you're using a small pool of spells that you've picked out until the game decides that the enemy you're facing needs this specific type of spell. One particular boss requires you to use quite a few different spells, and you can only have so many equipped at once, so more than a few times during the fight, your main enemy will be the menu. In conclusion, Don't bother with X-Blades. if you absolutely can't help yourself, go find the soundtrack or something, but the game is absolutely not worth the time it takes to buy it.

content:
ry 25
												Okay, going to say this, first and foremost: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME! IT IS NOT WORTH IT!The game is horrible. Without hardly any deviation, this is how the game goes: You start off in this room where you have to kill all these enemies until the game tells you to stop and move onto the next room, where you have to kill all these enemies until the game tells you to stop and move onto the next room, where you have to kill all these enemies until the game tells you to stop and move onto the next room, rinse and repeat, RINSE AND REPEAT, OVER, AND OVER, *AND OVER!* Repitition is the name of the game, here.The ruins where you "explore" are interesting to look at. Wanna learn more about them? Too bad, the game doesn't explain them! And Ayumi, the lead character, is nothing short of obnoxious! I HATE HER! I hate her personality, I hate how she dresses like a street walker, I HATE HER! And, yes, she is a BLATANT rip-off of Lara Croft, without any of the latter's charm, explorative abilities or puzzle-solving antics.The enemies are dumb as rocks, and while that can be dealt with easily, there is one kind of enemy that you face early on that is a pain to deal with, as if you're getting swarmed by ground-based enemies and five of these special enemies circle you, then there goes half your health and no, I am not kidding.I also had MAJOR lighting issues while playing it, at least on some stages. It was like the camera had its own shadow. And speaking of mechanics, swiping or shooting at destructible items is counter-intuitive. You need to break all items in the game to get 100%, but you can stand in front of a pot, hack and slash at it for about five or six swings, but it'll break at the sixth or seventh swipe. Stone coffins do show you hitting it, but nothing else does.Finally, something worth noting, this version was played on a Mac. I am aware that the Mac isn't a good system to play on, except I also owned this game on the XBox 360, which is said to be the best version. That's not saying much - I had the exact same issues with that version. However, as I mentioned, this was on a Mac, so, instead of doing a different port, they just made what is called a Wineskin (for those who don't know, it's an application that allows programs that were made for Windows to be played on Macs.) They did nothing to enhance the game in any way for the Mac.In the end, there is no possible way I can recommend this game. It's like they tried to make a game, like Golden Axe or Streets of Rage, but ended up sucking all of the charm out of those kind of games.In the end, I had more fun playing Superman 64.

												Can be summarized as "Mash M1 until the little red bar depletes." In each area you enter, you must kill the enemies until the bar on the bottom right of the screen is depleted, that's it. They will always spawn in the same spots and if you're lucky, they might start spawning different enemies. I often wondered if I was doing something wrong at first because this seemed so tedious but that is the way it's supposed to be. Come to the first boss I keep hitting him over and over but nothing seems to be happening. Surprise! That bar is now the health bar, and yes it does take 5-10 minutes of doing the same exact thing to kill the boss. Occasionally, you will enter rooms that contain some form of a "puzzle." For example, there is one room where you are trapped and must avoid spikes that go in a pattern for about five horrible minutes (and again, I thought was doing something wrong BUT NO IT'S JUST THE WAY THE GAME IS).There appears to be some barebones of a story but the voice acting and writing is just so awfully cringey that I could not manage to get through more than oen or two of the cutscenes. The game looks okay graphically but the design of the main character is frankly just creepy.The only saving grace is the soundtrack alone which is AWESOME.

content:
, 2014
												Score - 48/100Personal rating - Game-starved genre fans only need applyHad I played a demo - No purchase"You can't judge a book by its cover."For most things in life, that old adage rings true. First appearances are most often not representative of something's value. When it comes to video games though, there are a decent number of things that can be almost instantly determined, and such was my experience with X-Blades.The graphics are a strange dichotomy of fantastic and bad. The 3d modeling is acceptable, the animations are rather clunky, and the texture work and set-piece design are phenomenal enough to make you forget about it all. Until the cutscenes, anyway, which are SO low-resolution and SO compressed that you'll be looking for the Youtube quality button in the corner, trying to switch up from 360P. Thankfully, the game is extremely well-optimized, with my old desktop able to get framerates in low 100s at 1920x1200 with everything maxed (AA on 4x).Speaking of graphics, I can't type up a review of this game without mentioning its most advertised asset. I have seen some ridiculous fan service before, and seen main characters in AAA games that I would have hidden from my mother as a kid, but this game's heroine, Ayumi, takes things to an entirely new level.Her outfit is so ridiculous that she is seemingly naked from more angles than not. Her hair covers more of her body than all her clothes combined. Her boots cover more of her body than the rest of her clothes combined. Hell, even one boot covers more. Her thong literally disappears into her impossibly-tall butt crack, and the camera is far enough back that should you play all the way through this game, you will be treated to a full moon for 8 straight hours. Her bra-esque top is by far the most sensible thing about her outfit, and if that doesn't just highlight the absurdity of it all, I don't know what would.You know a game is pushing that envelope when the obligatory softcore-porn fanart pics come across as nothing but redundant. Don't get me wrong, I like a well-sculpted butt more than most, but this is getting ridiculous. I'm not lying when I say her outfit couldn't possibly be any skimpier unless it just consisted of strategically-placed k-tape and pasties.I am a sucker for good music in a game, and I'm happy to report this game satisfies. The driving soundtrack in this game is pretty great and more than once, I found myself nodding along happily while I slaughtered wave after wave of enemies. I even checked the game's data folder for MP3s so I could keep them (they're there, in .ogg). Even in just my short while with the game, however, I noticed themes being recycled, which is understandable yet unfortunate. In addition, the sounds are cheese-tastic. The voice acting is stretching to be considered B-quality, and all the other sounds are completely forgettable. While that in itself is not a problem, overall the game will not win any bonus points for audio.This might all sound pretty decent so far, but the real meat of the matter, the gameplay, is bland at best. There is one attack (the X button), and several unlockable skills. No combos, no strong/heavy attacks, no aerial launches, and no strategy. Just X, X, X, X, X, X, X, X, X, rage attack, X, X, X, X, X. It gets very repetitive very fast. While some people might not mind that kind of repetition, I don't think anyone would deny that a little bit of strategy would make the whole thing a lot more palatable.This is especially true since character movement is so disjointed and... clunky, for lack of a better word. Ayumi tears around the levels at full sprint, but doing anything else just breaks her rhythm. Attacking slows her down and leaves her vulnerable just slightly longer than it should, there is no dodge button, and jumping is entirely useless. There are no valuable aerial attacks, and jumping actually slows Ayumi down, so if you're trying to leap out of danger, you will come back down in worse shape than you left. If all you're doing is touching the left analog stick, Ayumi's movement is incredibly smooth and fluid, but as soon as you touch any other button, the action gets choppy and frustrating.Level design is rather lame as well. For the most part, each area just drops you in a little self-contained arena, where you will be spamming the X button over and over and over and over and over on little endlessly-respawning waves of weaklings until you earn enough rage (basically mana) to cast the one or two spells that can damage any applicable "boss" creatures. Repeat until he/she is dead, and move on to the next arena.Games of this genre are at their greatest when they set everything up for frantic high-speed slaughtering. This game introduces so many little quirks, niggles, and idiosyncracies that I just can't recommend it over any other similar game. I would suggest going and playing any of the Devil May Cry games, that new Metal Gear Rising game, or even this game's own spiritual successor Blades of Time (which is supposedly better in every way, and not a direct sequel).For the vast majority of things, it is undeniably true that you can't judge a book by its cover, but when fundamental things such as character controls and basic gameplay mechanics frustrate me and nothing other than music impresses me, I'm perfectly confident in my decision to skip this one. Take this review with a grain of salt, of course, as it is always possible that I'm just not the target market at all, and so this game went entirely over my head. I've always found the concept of "fun" to be more or less universal, so I kind of doubt it, but whatever.

YouTube™ Video: Random Opinion: X-Blades First Impressions 

			Views: 102		

			This is my first impressions. I didn't finish the game and i won't. Follow me on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Little_B_Gaming		

X-Blades try to be spectacle fighter like Devil May Cry, God of War and so on, but it's far, far away from them. Here you don't have different weapons to choose or set of move. You relay on two swords and guns which are useless (after upgrading the guns they start to become somewhat useful) and a lot of mashing buttons.After killing an enemy, you collect souls, which are the currency of the game, With them you can buy magic spells. You can equip four at any time. But they are almost the same!!! Lightning on sword, fire on sword, Earthquake or Fire Rage it doesn't matter. From time to time you see new skill is unlocked, you open the menu to check it and where is it? You have buy some of the available spells and then you see what is unlocked. But what if i don't want to? Well there is no choice. The spells are tight with the bosses, not all but still. For example, there is this werewolf looking boss (which i fought 3 times) For 20 min or more i didn't hurt him once, then out of frustration i open you tube. You have to buy a specific skill named Sparkling Sword to beat him. How can I know that?! There is no indication that you need it. This is the same thing for some of the other bosses. And the fights with them are too long. For activating spell you need Rage. This is why you use the swords, other than that as i wrote they are useless, so most of the time you count on spell with area of effect, like Fire Rage. Later in the game the skills are quite expensive, so prepare for grinding. The difference between area of effect spells are the animation for each one. They take you out of the action and after that the camera is in weird angle. Games like this have some sort of move to avoid attacks. Here you can buy one, but it's not that useful and a lot of attacks become hard or impossible to avoid.Graphics are good, but the cutscenes are bad, they look worse than the in-game graphics. Level design is boring, just ruins and they are basically arenas. To move to the next area you have to kill all enemies on screen.The music is okay, rock and metal tracks, probably you won't remember it. Same thing can be said about the story. You play as Ayumi, treasure hunter and she touch something and she is cursed. It's completely forgettable.I mentioned you don't have different set of moves. This isn't quite true. In the game you collect three types of artifacts. When you find enough, you gain more life or some moves for the swords or new skills for the guns (then they become somewhat useful). Let me buy them, I don't want look around just for upgrading my airstrike, which is useless!!!I can go on and on with the negativity. There is some pleasure in the mindless action, but it won't last long. I didn't expect AAA game, but me some bad design decisions ruin the potential of X-Blades. It's not the worst game i've ever played It's often on sale if you have some interest, but don't even bother.Pros: nice visuals, okay soundtrack, some mindless action, responsive controls Cons: boring level design, no debt to the combat, repetitive, some skills/spells are directly tight with the bosses and it's not at least hinted what you need to buy for them, annoying heroine, forgettable story

y 12, 2016
												Back in 2009, many games tried too hard to be God of War/Devil May Cry and failed miserably.I remember this game back then, I was like "Wow, this game looks like ♥♥♥♥..." and now that I got it for free and I'm 6 or so years in the future, I shouldn't bother anymore but.... wow, this game IS ♥♥♥♥.-The combat is dreadfull. You smash the X button in hope of hitting anything, but some enemies just run away, can't be hit or are way too small to be hit. Every ♥♥♥♥ing move from bosses will stagger you CONSTANTLY, which is infuriating, specially when they have godlike homming fireballs that chase you even in reverse.-Bosses can't be hit by your swords, you'll have to kill them with magic, the problem is that bosses  have WAY TOO MUCH hp, and the only way to regain "mana" is to kill enemies around them, which are more annoying than the boss itself.-Dodging is USELESS. Doesn't respond correctly, doesn't do sh*t. You have to get the teleportation skill ASAP.-Enemies are dumb and infuriating, specially the small crabs. They make a mosh around you and don't let you move.-Character design is stupid. I can't take this game serious. The main character fights using a G-string, for christ sakes.-The story? I couldn't give a rat's a*ss to it. Just skipped every cutscene without thinking twice.... and I could go on.I got this game for free, and I shouldn't be complaining, but time is money, and what a waste of my time.I'll probably try it again in the future. I always give second chances, not that I intend to becoming a fan any time soon.UPDATE: This is it. This game just broke the record of most annoying enemies in a single game. Enemies that run away from you, are too small to get hit, fly away or fly to high so you can't hit them, enemies with stupid homing attacks that follow you even in reverse, enemies that pop out of nowhere and hit you whitout you even knowing, enemies that hide inside walls, bosses that take way too much damage to die, attacks that stagger you everytime. enemies that surround you and don't let you move.For f*ck sakes. Why did I even insist?

												In X-Blades, the player takes on the role of the enchanting heroine Ayumi, who survives a breathtaking dance of blades through the Hordes of Darkness. The long-haired beautiful anime, with her pistol blades and mind-blowing leaps, whirls and swirls from one fantastic level to the next. In brief: An anime-style, opulent hack n' slay spectacle for fans of entertaining action games. X-Blades creates a fantastic universe around the attractive heroine, who has to fend off innumerable monsters and imposing boss opponents with her power and tactics. A long list of all sorts of magic spells widens the range of potential forms of attack. Once Ayumi has collected enough experience points, she can activate new skills. The anime-style level design is what really gives X-Blades its special flair. Around 40 magical indoor and outdoor worlds dazzle in an enthralling rhapsody of color. Action and magical effects are impressively incorporated through the use of cinema stylistics such as bullet time or motion blurring.

er 25, 2015
												Oh my god. Where do I even begin.A brief explanation of the plot/overview of this game, I guess (might be inaccurate since I gave up less than an hour after playing):This is a hack-and-slash game where a greedy lone wolf treasure hunter ignores the advice of an ancient temple guardian, touches a magic object (that she was directly informed by said guardian that the power within the object is completely fatal to humans; by the way, she is, in fact, a human, so she is no exclusion to this reality), and gets the ♥♥♥♥ cursed out of her.Alright, onto the specifics.This game tries to be fast-paced and cool with a sexy heroine main character to keep people interested (i.e. the half-dressed protagonist that has jello for breasts that will dramatically move around even if you are just walking, and whose ♥♥♥ is always hanging out in hopes that you stay focused on that as often as possible; I was able to ignore both things and focus on the absolute terror that was the gameplay since I have no interest in either of those subjects [laughs in aseuxal]), but in reality, this game is just a wildly unpleasant experience all around.The movement controls are disorienting as ♥♥♥♥. Your default movement speed is "a desperate sprint for your life." If you jump too close to a ledge, Ayumi will abruptly roll forward instead of doing the logical thing and jumping up. The double jumping is also commonly unresponsive.The melee combat is standard at best. It controls like a hack-and-slash game. Run up to common enemies, and spam a button at everyone until they stop moving. That much is at least correct.The gun combat is honestly funny as ♥♥♥♥. If you are locked onto an enemy, Ayumi will not miss a single ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ shot, even if they are all the way across the area from you. In the second level, I was practically in tears when I became a sentry gun and skipped enemies across the beach with my guns like a rock getting skipped over water. Ayumi being a sentient aimbot program is fairly useful, I guess.The magic combat is okay. In order to use magic, you need to build up "rage" by either attacking enemies until you have enough rage to use a spell, or by holding down the key/button that your spell is bound to until her rage is charged up enough to use the attack. Since this game likes to fling large hordes of enemies in your direction at once, you typically have enough rage to last you the whole fight.The combat interface as a whole is rather confusing. Nine times out of ten, I did not even know that I was getting hurt. Usually, in games with a health/damage feature, you know when you are getting attacked since your character will typically make a noise or flinch or something when harmed, or maybe the screen will flash red for a second or whatever. Ayumi does nothing if it is not a big enough attack to stagger her. I kept looking up at her health and getting surprised at how much I had lost without noticing anything.Ayumi as a character made me want to stop playing before the opening cinematic for the first level even ended. She sounds like the "mean girl in high school," and she talks as if she is above everyone else. For example, in her very first sentence, she outright states that she is "the best treasure hunter ever." That opinion is open to a staggering amount of debate, have some ♥♥♥♥ing humility. Later on, when the aforementioned temple guardian warns her that the object that she is trying to steal will straight-up kill her and tells her to leave while she still can (without trying to harm her, by the way; he was literally going to just let her turn around and walk out of the temple unharmed and without a fight), her reaction was to flip her hair, roll her eyes, adamantly state "yeah right," try to steal the object anyway while the guardian was not looking at her, and then get cursed like a dumbass since she thought that grabbing an object that is "fatal to humans" was a bright idea. For the "best treasure hunter in the world," she sure does make some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ thoughtless decisions. I am almost completely certain that all of her previous heists up to that point were from children that were holding a coin that they found on the ground.On a related note to Ayumi, the physics in this game are abysmal. I am not talking about her earthquake jello breasts again, either. I am talking about her three ponytails. I have never seen hair move that erratically in my whole life. In every cutscene or moment of gameplay where she was moving around too fast, her ponytails went ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. They looked like the tentacles of the Kraken emerging from the waters and searching for a ship full of sailors to pull into the depths of the sea. This was a game for the Xbox 360 and PS3, too. Those consoles had pretty good graphic capabilities for their time. I am not forgiving this one. If her hair was that unstable, they should have changed it to something more usable.This game, at the time of writing this review, is on sale for $10. That is the normal retail price. But, from what I have experienced, this game certainly is not even remotely worth that much money. If you seriously want to buy the game that badly, please wait for the price to drop hard first.((I got this game for free from Bundle Stars as a Christmas "gift." I am almost completely certain that they no longer want me to be a customer of theirs.))

												In X-Blades you play as the fierce Treasure Hunter Ayumi as she unveils the secrets of a hidden artifact. X-blades provides quick combat, a range of spells and multiple levels. You can choose between magic, swords and guns to attack the numerous enemies you find throughout the temple. You may need to wait a bit before buying the more powerful spells but the game allows you obtain most of them without wasting time grinding.Now for the cons. X-Blades starts off bland and doesn't get any better. The boss battles are more tedious than challenging and you end up using the same one spell to go through most of the game. Hitting enemies doesn't really provide any feedback and you end up dying due to the terribel camera angle and/or a silly mistake. It doesn't take long for you to get bored at looking at the same brown temple walls every SINGLE STAGE! Honestly, throw some different environments in there.Now this may be subjective but if you're going to make a scantily clad heroine then at least give her some assests to work with. Honestly, it would have been better if they gave her some armor to cover up. Oh well, at least give them 2 points for trying.All in all, I would avoid this game at full price. Sure I had fun with the game but it gave me  more frustration than enjoyment. If you're really curious I would recommend picking this game up when it is at least 70% off.
