												I know no one reads these or cares what they say, but while I wait for Blades of Time to download I want to leave a short review;This game tries to oversell itself as a stylish 3rd person action game in thhe vein of DmC, Bayonetta, or any of Platnium's work. This is false.While there is some "style" to it, it doesn't have that tight heart beat that makes the combat flow like in those game. This game more is along the line sof Gauntlet or Dynasty Warriors - sans the strategy,It's a "mash X to win" game (X for 360 pad users) with a few special moves you ccan activate via a single button press rather than a combo. You can map the skills to left bumper, right bumper, Y, and B. Though, they stupidly made dodge-roll double-tap-forward+jump which is awkward to execute, so I can guarentee once you have the ability to unlock the "teleport" skill, that will ALWAYS be mapped to one of your 4 slots.The game is short, and the opening is rough - with the beginning mostly being "mash, mash, mash, earthquake....mash mash mash, earthquake." but after the first hour you begin unlocking more skills and eventually, this short game turns into a fun little romp.Don't take the story seriously, it makes no sense. Play the game solely for it's mechanics, which aren't very deep, but I beat it and had a decent little time with it. I don't regret my purchase and it sold me on playing the (supposedly) superior spiritual successor. Give it a whirl - just don't expect something great. It's good and I think worth the $10 asking price even though the game has glaring flaws and seems like it was made on a very low budget.

												This is a weird game. It's sometimes very fun, and sometimes ridiculously boring and horrible.To start off, the story is poor and almost non existent, with even worse voice acting to accompany the few cut scenes.The levels are okay sometimes, but other times they take forever, especially when you have to sit there and figure out what you need to kill to pass the level. This takes even longer when certain enemies take certain spells to kill, but the enemies are never consistent. Sometimes you need to use fire, and later you many need to use lightning. All the while you are trying to figure this out, you are getting mobbed by never ending enemies.Tat being said though, the game is at a comfortable difficulty, so its not really all that frustrating.Though the most frustrating thing is the toughest enemies you will find in this game...pots. Dear god those pots. The hit detection is so horrendous, you will spend a good 30 seconds trying to break a pot. They seem to just break whenever they feel like it...it's so annoying.Oh and rolling is horrendous too...yeah, rolling. Rolling is so hard and random to acheive that there are two levels dedicated to just managing to pull off rolling three times to beat the level. It's a disaster.Jumping is a mess as well, though still easily doable.Some good things about the game is the combat is ok, with plenty of upgrades and spells to keep things interesting. Other than spells, you can use swords and guns to attack foes, making for nice, varied gameplay. There are hidden artifacts in the levels to find too, which give you special upgrades.The best part about the game though is your character, Ayumi. You get to enjoy the nice view of a woman clad only in underwear and a few shreds of armor, but even this does not distract from all the downsides of the game.Overall its not the worst game I've ever played, not even close really, but it sure isn't good. I wouldn't recommend spending more than $2.00 on this

												A fairly low budget, quick paced, hack and slash game with repetitive gameplay. When I say quick paced and repetitive, I mean that the action itself feels fast and you may need to concentrate to keep up with everything. It is repetitive because there is not alot of enemy or level variaty, and the few levels only feel long because they keep throwing hordes of enemies at you.The story, what little there is, started out interresting enough to get me going, but leaves pretty much everything unanswered. Maybe there's a book or something I don't know about, the game sure doesn't explain anything, just leaves you with the feeling of 'I would love to know more about everything'.That said, did I enjoy the game? Yep.The combat feels satisfying when you figure it out, even if it's not particularly deep. It's at the level where you might call it brainless action, but every once in a while you need to wake up another brain cell to figure out the right solution, which I at least enjoy once in a while.I think I bought it discounted to 5€ or maybe less. At that price, I can recommend it, if you're into these kind of games.

												X-Blades is a fun hack and slash game with a few flaws.The pros:  It's fairly long.  The world looks good with a kind of cartoony style.  It has multiple story paths.  Quite a bit of different skills you can choose from.  You're looking at ♥♥♥ all day ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)The const:  Higher difficulty is just more spam, you're often stun locked by the constant damage animation because about 15 enemies are attacking you non-stop.  The game has extra DRM. Which I couldn't properly  activate with my CD key and I ended up downloading a cracked exe instead. It normally tells you to contact support on some dead forum and I didn't feel like waiting 2 weeks for an answer.  At some point in the game the audio just craps out, however this could be because of the crack I installed.  Some things like healing end up becoming ridiculously overpriced in the end-game, where you need them.Despite the flaws, I had a lot of fun with this game.Pick it up if you like hack and slash games and definitely pick it up in sale.

												This game is not the best, but it is worth the 10 dollars or your regional equivilant. This game has all the things it needs to be considered a good hack and slash game: good keyboard controls,good progression, fun enemies, and some fun varying combat. Anyone that says this game is button mashy has not used spells spells are effective and fun to use, and like any good hack and slash rpg, will require careful planning on where to use them on the hard difficulty. The protagonist is a funny, overconfident, and arrogent female lead, this maybe a turn of to some but I enjoyed the humor. It is kinda annoying to see an obviously adult character act like a child, but never since Lollipop Chainsaw Massacare have we had a character like this that is so well written, so I don't really car. This game does have it's flaws though to change resolution options you have to reset the game BEFORE you can. This would be more acceptable if the game put it in the options menu and then auto saved and reset, but it doesn't. It makes you quit then start again which dosen't even matter because changing it crashes your game at random intervals. Thats right cant change resolution. Luckily the game runs well so you should have no trouble running it  on 1080. I was recording without an ssd on low graphics on 1080 on what is practiclly half potatoe, and still kept 30. If you hoped on recording this sad news, game will crash randomly at times with most software available. As well the game shows most tool tips with bot controller and keyboard mouse bindings, which dosen't cause issues, but is still really irratating. My Final verdict is that this game is indeed worth ten big ones, but may not be the best for a YouTuber or Twitch Streamer to get, however the games has a great character, fun combat, interesting skills, and a kick ♥♥♥ sound track. If you are a fan of Hack & Slash RPGs, and are at least OK with the anime style, this game is worth the buy.

												TL;DR For a dollar with trading cards, it's an almost decent hack 'n' slash. What I feel are poor mechanics sour the experience. The devs absolutely learned from the mistakes in X-Blades and made Blades of Time a great game. Get BoT instead. EDIT: Art direction is lovely but to say succinctly what I did in a rambling way: Blades of Time is fun. X-Blades really isn't.I care not for anime sexuality.I bought this game.*GASP* How can that be?!X-Blades is the predecessor to Blades of Time; Blades of Time is a remake/reimagining of X-Blades. I got BoT in a bundle. I very much enjoyed it. I bought X-Blades in the hopes of encouraging the dev's to include Cards for BoT / Achievements for X-Blades.I did not fully grasp the significance of "reimagining." X-Blades is horrible when compared to Blades of Time. My saying so is unfair, of course, but also truth.With X-Blades, I was hoping to relive the glory days of PS2 platformers (Sly Cooper, Jak & Daxter, Ratchet & Clank, Beyond Good & Evil, KyA, Vex, etc. etc.). LOL upon further research, X-Blades was released for the subsequent generation... so my hopes were dashed from the start.Several reviews compare X-Blades to Devil May Cry; I'm pretty sure I compared BoT to DMC. X-Blades is similar to DMC only superficially: the targeting and combo system, the sword/gun-play, the double-jump, the fact that you fall slower while shooting, and of course the monsters (are vaguely similar). Other than that, X-Blades is a hodgepodge of (bad) mechanics.You're a nimble nearly nude female treasure hunting... n-nin... er s-samur... er anime. Yeah. You can swing your blades and shoot the shooty-things with the quickness; you can run (in the classic "back-bent-at-a-45-degree-angle-for-speed-and-style" pose) LIKE a ninja. When it comes to being swarmed by enemies... Ayumi moves like Zero from BoT: heavy and slow, tank-like. I'm playing with a controller and I don't even know how to dodge; I got the Teleport power, but you can only use it when your feet are planted firmly on the ground. There is no manual lock-on to enemies; moving the camera over enemies does it automatically. This makes targeting the bosses amidst the throngs of grunts a chore. The Store Page doesn't mention controller support; you can play with a controller but there are no options like Right Stick or Vibration Sensitivity (I THINK you can remap buttons but IDK). Speaking of mobs, you best get that Teleport power early on and refrain from jumping like you'd figure the agile MILF with a baby's face (yeah...) should be able to. Else, you'll float atop the mobs or, somehow, one of the grunts will end up on top of you, out of reach of your blades.Combos... I don't even know. I don't even know how the points work, actually. Your melee attacks are the only thing that multiply your combo; if you use guns or powers, you get nothing. In BoT, you could run all over the map with the (pretty much useless) points ("souls," I think) following you tirelessly - you were never going to lose any of them. In X-Blades it seems if you get too far from the points, they just disappear. If you're working on a mob, of course, the multiplier is multiplied. I think if you get hit once, you lose every bit of those banked points, rather than it just resetting to zero and getting the points you had earned. I like this idea, it is, how you say, "hardcore." When you can't maneuver well enough on your own to preserve that combo, when there isn't a block/parry; other reviews that say "The game is nothing more than spamming LMB" are correct. I hate to admit that, since that could be argued for SEVERAL games, but with X-Blades, it's absolutely true.There is a bit of a prologue and you end up being sent to some other... dimension. The beach you spawn on is apparently a hub(?). I cleared the waves upon waves of enemies, went through the door that opened, cleared the boss and those waves, didn't find another door, went back through the first, back on the beach, cleared those waves, didn't find another door, went back through the first door, and had enough. I'm certain some sorts of new mechanics / gimmicks will be employed throughout the game but I'm not sure I have the fortitude to deal with the just plain poor combat (which is, no doubt, the entirety of the game); monotony. Get Blades of Time; it is fantastic (though Ayumi is (")a bit more(") conservative).

												I got this game for a dollar with a coupon.  It's hard to say no to a game for a dollar but normally it sells for a few dollars on steam. The Good:  -  This game is not a bad ~concept~.   Cel shaded female anime character wielding two gun swords, who can shoot, slash, and cast spells you unlock with souls.  Character moves quickly like sonic the hedgehog, so think a quick moving sonic the hedgehog hack and slash that collects souls instead of rings... except the souls look like rings?  Not a terrible concept.  With pumped up metal music.The Bad:     -  The graphics are not there.  This can be understandable in low budget first game. They are not downright terrible by any stretch of the imagination but with the high speed it makes me almost nauseus.  Feels like spawn rate is just too high / quick on monsters.-  The cut scenes keep going choppy on my computer.The Ugly:    - The way you assign the spells and buy the spells to the menu, the system is just kind of clunky and not easy on the eyes.   I think some improvements here with color scheme, easy UI, would really really help this game.-  Why the music does this horrible garbled thing on my end I still fail to understand.  The music is generally fuzzy but it ups the level to a car radio in a tunnel during battles.-   Tiny menu button in the corner when you press tab for spell buying is the only way to close the game.  Ctrl-Alt-Delete caused it to just become angry and make it's static loopy metal track go insane on my computer. Do yourself a favor and don't try to kill this program it's one of those that can't be killed and just gets more angry.As it stands now I wouldn't recommend it, but unlike some games on steam I wouldn't outright say it's a bad concept either.  The concept of a high paced anime hack and slash is really a great idea.

												Think about God of War and everything that made it great aside from mashing a button to open up a chest. Now take everything and make it slightly annoying; the result is more or less X-Blades. It's a semi-fun mindless buttonmasher with minor annoyances thrown in; certain enemies are so short it's hard to hit them with your blades, bullets and spells don't always go where you want them to, the plot is just shy of nonexistant, pots are somehow immune to your swords unless you get them at just the perfect angle, certain rooms have enemies that can only be defeated in a certain way but it's up to you to guess how, certain mechanics are explained long after it would've been nice to know about them, and there's no dedicated dodge button/stick. Your rage(mana) decays unless you're in combat or getting punched in the face, so you can run into situations where you have to choice but to let some monstrosity gnaw on you for a bit while you wait to get angry enough to use the only ability that will harm it.While not good, it's not exactly bad. It's just a shame to see that it had potential yet missed the mark and dove off the cliff instead. Not really worth it at full price; I would not recommend purchasing it unless it's on sale. Also, much bloom. Wear shades.

												Not the most serious or grandest of games, but in the end I did find it enjoyable and worth it, and no, I'm not influenced by Ayumi's assets, not in the slightest, not at all....ok yes maybe!Most levels are nice and short so you don't have to spend hours and hours over a level; think more like 10 minutes a level, and maybe 15-20 for the harder ones. For some people, this may be a con, but not everyone has all the free time to spend as others do.Another bit of a con is that her voice is rather annoying when she speaks; it doesn't quite match the character at all.In the end though, I enjoyed the game. It's a nice slasher game and the music and visuals aren't half bad either. I would recommend though that you buy it on sale.Some useful tips though for new players:- There is a good and a bad ending which is influenced by your "decisions". What is not hinted at all is that there "decisions" are not conversation based choices but rather based on the Spells/Abilities that you choose to learn (broad hint, "bad" spells have a colour/description that is rather obvious in hindsight). So be warned, if you want the good ending, hold off a bit until you have the choice of the "good" magics. You'll know by the name. Try not to end up like me who reached almost halfway before realising this and had to start all over because I wanted the good ending.- Check your Beastiary often; it can be a huge help when countering some of the harder enemies.- You have to spend souls on upgrades and whilst you may feel to be cheap in your spending, don't worry, you'll have plenty extra by then end of the game, and those upgrades to Regeneration and Form Duration are well worth the cost.- And speaking of souls, you can also find them in breakable items, like statues and pots. And the items can also hide valuable upgrade parts/artifacts. So take the time to slash/shoot everything you can.- There is also an area where you get an outfit upgrade, but, if you like how she looks, you can choose to not take it....because it covers more, lol- The nice thing with dying is that you'll restart the level with all the enemies respawned but with all the souls and upgrades that you died with.- There was one item of note, a scroll that halved the cost of any item/upgrade. The bad part, well you don't have a choice of whether to use it or not, it is automatically used on your very next purchase. Lets say you've been saving it for that (otherwise very costly) upgrade/spell, and you're in a fight and need to heal, well guess what, if you buy a heal, then say goodbye scroll. So better to use it before a fight so you can make your best choice.- There are a few areas that involve jumping around. What can help is after you jump (or double jump) is to start shooting (or slashing). It slows down your descent and can help to extend the distance you cover while "falling". Really useful in some areas to get to hard to reach items or ledges. I recommend shooting over slashing however, as there is the chance that you do a special slash move that makes you move downwards....and maybe plummet to your death.- In her special forms, her movement and attack speed increases, so make good use of it in those harder levels. I also noticed that her Rage (i.e. mana) may have taken longer to deplete when using abilities.

												It plays like Brutal Legend mixed with Devil May Cry 4. And I can safely say that I have never wanted to punch a protagonist in the face so badly, and this is after playing DMC, Shadow Warrior, and Duke Nukem. There is only a light attack, with it seems the rest of the buttons being rerserved for magic attacks that require "rage", a resource that constantly drains, even in combat. There is also guns, just like devil may cry. A style meter, just like devil may cry. Even the fact that gunshots keep you in the air, just like devil may cry. I think(?) there is a doge roll allocated to the right stick. Needs confirmation. The combat itself is so basic, dominant strategy takes over any creativity.It also seems like parts of this game are meant to show off this characters ♥♥♥ and ♥♥♥♥. The very first level has you lock on to an enemy that's in the air.Unfortunately, you can't even see the enemy, just a butt. Feminism aside, it's not even a good ♥♥♥. Like, remember that Lady Gaga type lady in DMC 4. Remember how hot she was? Too bad the girl here isn't. PLUS I WANT TO PUNCH HER IN HER FACE. She is one of the most annoying characters I have ever seen, and it seems like the only reason she's designed the way she was was to make teenage boys all hot and bothered. I want to say that for 99 cents, you should consider getting it....but no. Most of the  positive reviews seem to be people who only played an hour or two into. If thats what it takes to finish the game, then it's garbage considering it's not an indie release (I've seen this for sale at walmart). They also might be liars. Fans of Devil May Cry, not really. I should finish this game, for the sake of clarity. I should finish to see if there is a slight glimmer of hope. But I don't really see this going anywhere.

												I don't know what those people are smoking who claim that this game has a deep and meaningful story but that's not even a close to true. I also think that hack and slash does not require any epic lore to be a good game. Anyway, playing this game through once was fun and relaxing with normal mode but I cannot see myself playing this again for a long time. So replay value is pretty much a zero.Graphics are decent, controls may be a little bit clumsy but good enough. Combat works and there's a nice variation of different spells and skills to spice the gameplay a bit. What I did miss was some indication when you actually took damage, and how much. Of course it would be a nice to see how much enemy took damage with some specific skill or combo. Dodging is also missing completely and it's replaced with fast running speed that allows you to kite almost any enemies as long as you want.If you are truly hack & slash fan I guess you can get something out of this. For the rest, I think there's better hack & slash games for the same price or even cheaper.
